panels.description:
### Per-instance runs
Number of times a compactor instance triggers a compaction across all tenants that it manages.
panels.title: Per-instance runs / sec

panels.description:
### Tenants compaction progress
In a multi-tenant cluster, display the progress of tenants that are compacted while compaction is running.
panels.title: Tenants compaction progress

panels.description:
### Longest time since last successful run
Displays the amount of time since the most recent successful execution
of the compactor.
The value shown will be for the compactor replica that has the longest time since its
last successful run.
The table to the right shows a summary for all compactor replicas.

If there is no time value, one of the following messages might appear:

- If you see "No compactor data" in this panel, that means that no compactors are active yet.

- If you see "No successful runs" in this panel, that means that compactors are active, but none
  of them were successfully executed yet.

These might be expected - for example, if you just recently restarted your compactors,
they might not have had a chance to complete their first compaction run.
However, if these messages persist, you should check the health of your compactors.

result.text: No successful runs since startup yet

panels.title: Longest time since last successful run

panels.description:
### Last successful run per-compactor replica
Displays the compactor replicas, and for each, shows how long it has been since
its last successful compaction run.

The value in the status column is based on how long it has been since the last successful compaction.

- Okay: less than 2 hours
- Delayed: more than 2 hours
- Late: more than 6 hours
- Very late: more than 12 hours

If the status of any compactor replicas are *Late* or *Very late*, check their health.
panels.title: Last successful run per-compactor replica

panels.description:
### Estimated Compaction Jobs
Estimated number of compaction jobs based on latest version of bucket index. Ingesters upload new blocks every 2 hours (shortly after 01:00 UTC, 03:00 UTC, 05:00 UTC, etc.),
and compactors should process all of them within 2h interval. If this graph regularly goes to zero (or close to zero) in 2 hour intervals, then compaction works as designed.

Metric with number of compaction jobs is computed from blocks in bucket index, which is updated regularly. Metric doesn't change between bucket index updates, even if
there were compaction jobs finished in this time. When computing compaction jobs, only jobs that can be executed at given moment are counted. There can be more
jobs, but if they are blocked, they are not counted in the metric. For example if there is a split compaction job pending for some time range, no merge job
covering the same time range can run. In this case only split compaction job is counted toward the metric, but merge job isn't.

In other words, computed number of compaction jobs is the minimum number of compaction jobs based on latest version of bucket index.
panels.title: Estimated Compaction Jobs

panels.description:
### Source blocks age
The difference between the maximum timestamp of the block being compacted and the current time.
A steadily increasing value indicates that the compactor cannot keep up with the produced blocks by the ingesters.
Increase the number of compactors when this value is consistently increasing.
panels.title: Source blocks age

panels.description:
### TSDB compactions / sec
Rate of TSDB compactions. Single TSDB compaction takes one or more input blocks and produces one or more (during "split" phase) output blocks.
panels.title: TSDB compactions / sec

panels.description:
### TSDB compaction duration
Display the amount of time that it has taken to run a single TSDB compaction.
panels.title: TSDB compaction duration

panels.description:
### Tenants with largest number of blocks
The 10 tenants with the largest number of blocks.
panels.title: Tenants with largest number of blocks

panels.description:
### Queue duration

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue duration

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length (per pod)

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length (per user)

panels.description:
### Queue duration

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue duration

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length (per pod)

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length (per user)

panels.description:
### Intervals per query
The average number of split queries (partitioned by time) executed a single input query.
panels.title: Intervals per query

targets.expr:
# Query the new metric introduced in Mimir 2.10.
(
  sum by(request_type) (rate(cortex_frontend_query_result_cache_hits_total{$read_path_matcher}[$__rate_interval]))
  /
  sum by(request_type) (rate(cortex_frontend_query_result_cache_requests_total{$read_path_matcher}[$__rate_interval]))
)
# Otherwise fallback to the previous general-purpose metrics.
or
(
  label_replace(
    sum (
      rate(thanos_cache_hits_total{name="frontend-cache", $read_path_matcher}[$__rate_interval])
    )
    /
    sum (
      rate(thanos_cache_requests_total{name=~"frontend-cache", $read_path_matcher}[$__rate_interval])
    ),
    "request_type", "query_range", "", "")
)

panels.description:
### Query results cache skipped
The % of queries whose results could not be cached.
It is tracked for each split query when the splitting by interval is enabled.
panels.title: Query results cache skipped

rows.title: Query-frontend  query splitting and results cache

panels.description:
### Sharded queries ratio
The % of queries that have been successfully rewritten and executed in a shardable way.
This panel only takes into account the type of queries that are supported by query sharding (eg. range queries).
panels.title: Sharded queries ratio

panels.description:
### Number of sharded queries per query
The number of sharded queries that have been executed for a single input query. It only tracks queries that
have been successfully rewritten in a shardable way.
panels.title: Number of sharded queries per query
Number of store-gateways hit per query
Refetches of missing blocks per query

panels.description:
### Consistency checks failed
Rate of queries that had to run with consistency checks and those checks failed. A failed consistency check means that some of at least one block which had to be queried wasn't present in any of the store-gateways.
panels.title: Consistency checks failed

panels.description:
### Rejected queries
The proportion of all queries received by queriers that were rejected for some reason.
panels.title: Rejected queries

panels.description:
### Blocks queried / sec by compaction level
Increased volume of lower levels (for example levels 1 and 2) can indicate that the compactor is not keeping up.
In that case the store-gateway will start serving more blocks which aren't that well compacted.
panels.title: Blocks queried / sec by compaction level

targets.expr:
sum by(data_type) (
  # Exclude "chunks refetched".
  rate(cortex_bucket_store_series_data_size_fetched_bytes_sum{component="store-gateway", stage!="refetched", cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))"}[$__rate_interval])
)

sum by(data_type) (
  # Exclude "chunks processed" to only count "chunks returned", other than postings and series.
  rate(cortex_bucket_store_series_data_size_touched_bytes_sum{component="store-gateway", stage!="processed",cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))"}[$__rate_interval])
)

panels.description:
### Series batch preloading efficiency
This panel shows the % of time reduced by preloading, for Series() requests which have been
split to 2+ batches. If a Series() request is served within a single batch, then preloading
is not triggered, and thus not counted in this measurement.

targets.expr:
# Clamping min to 0 because if preloading not useful at all, then the actual value we get is
# slightly negative because of the small overhead introduced by preloading.
clamp_min(1 - (
    sum(rate(cortex_bucket_store_series_batch_preloading_wait_duration_seconds_sum{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))"}[$__rate_interval]))
    /
    sum(rate(cortex_bucket_store_series_batch_preloading_load_duration_seconds_sum{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))"}[$__rate_interval]))
), 0)

panels.title: Series batch preloading efficiency

panels.description:
### Blocks currently owned
This panel shows the number of blocks owned by each store-gateway replica.
For each owned block, the store-gateway keeps its index-header on disk, and
eventually loaded in memory (if index-header lazy loading is disabled, or lazy loading
is enabled and the index-header was loaded).
panels.title: Blocks currently owned

panels.description:
### Index-header lazy load gate latency
Time spent waiting for a turn to load an index header. This time is not included in "Index-header lazy load duration."
panels.title: Index-header lazy load gate latency
Chunks attributes in-memory cache hit ratio

list.description: Choose between showing latencies based on low precision classic or high precision native histogram metrics.
list.label: Latency metrics
list.name: latency_metrics

panels.content:
This dashboard shows health metrics for the read path. It is broken into sections for each service on the read path, and organized by the order in which the read request flows.
Incoming queries travel from the gateway query frontend query scheduler querier ingester and/or store-gateway (depending on the time range of the query).
For each service, there are 3 panels showing (1) requests per second to that service, (2) average, median, and p99 latency of requests to that service, and (3) p99 latency of requests to each instance of that service.

The dashboard also shows metrics for the 4 optional caches that can be deployed: the query results cache, the metadata cache, the chunks cache, and the index cache.
These panels will show no data if the caches are not deployed.

Lastly, it also includes metrics for how the ingester and store-gateway interact with object storage.

panels.description:
### Instant queries per second
Rate of instant queries per second being made to the system.
Includes both queries made to the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API as
well as queries from the ruler.
panels.title: Instant queries / sec

panels.description:
### Range queries per second
Rate of range queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Range queries / sec

panels.description:
### "Label names" queries per second
Rate of "label names" endpoint queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Label names queries / sec

panels.description:
### "Label values" queries per second
Rate of specific "label values" endpoint queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Label values queries / sec

panels.description:
### Series queries per second
Rate of series queries per second being made to
Mimir via the <tt>/prometheus</tt> API.
panels.title: Series queries / sec

panels.description:
### Requests / sec

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Latency (Time in Queue)

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Latency (Time in Queue)

panels.description:
### Queue length

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Queue length

panels.description:
### 99th Percentile Latency by Expected Query Component

The query-scheduler creates subqueues broken out by which query components (ingester, store-gateway, or both) the querier is expected to fetch data from to service the query.

Queries which have not had an expected query component determined are labeled 'unknown'.

If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: 99th Percentile Latency by Expected Query Component

panels.description:
### 50th Percentile Latency by Expected Query Component

The query-scheduler creates subqueues broken out by which query components (ingester, store-gateway, or both) the querier is expected to fetch data from to service the query.

Queries which have not had an expected query component determined are labeled 'unknown'.

If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: 50th Percentile Latency by Expected Query Component

panels.description:
### Average Latency by Expected Query Component

The query-scheduler creates subqueues broken out by which query components (ingester, store-gateway, or both) the querier is expected to fetch data from to service the query.

Queries which have not had an expected query component determined are labeled 'unknown'.

If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Average Latency by Expected Query Component

rows.title: Query-scheduler Latency (Time in Queue) Breakout by Expected Query Component

panels.description:
### 99th Percentile Inflight Requests by Query Component vs. Total Connected Queriers

The query-scheduler tracks query requests inflight between the scheduler and the connected queriers, broken out by which query component (ingester, store-gateway) the querier is expected to fetch data from to service the query.

Queries which require data from both ingesters and store-gateways are counted in each category, so the sum of the two categories may exceed the true total number of queries inflight.

If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: 99th Percentile Inflight Requests by Query Component vs. Total Connected Queriers

panels.description:
### Requests / sec
This panel shows ingester query requests from all sources: the main query path, and the remote ruler query path, if in use. The data shown is as reported by ingesters.
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Latency
This panel shows ingester query requests from all sources: the main query path, and the remote ruler query path, if in use. The data shown is as reported by ingesters.
panels.title: Latency

panels.description:
### Per ingester pod p99 latency
This panel shows ingester query requests from all sources: the main query path, and the remote ruler query path, if in use. The data shown is as reported by ingesters.
panels.title: Per ingester pod p99 latency

rows.title: Ingester - query requests from all sources

panels.description:

This panel shows ingester query requests from just the main query path (ie. excluding the ruler query path, if enabled). The data shown is as reported by queriers.

This panel shows ingester query requests from just the main query path (ie. excluding the ruler query path, if enabled). The data shown is as reported by queriers.

This panel shows store-gateway query requests from all sources: the main query path, and the remote ruler query path, if in use. The data shown is as reported by store-gateways.
panels.title: Latency

panels.description:
### Requests / sec
This panel shows store-gateway query requests from just the main query path (ie. excluding the ruler query path, if enabled). The data shown is as reported by queriers.
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Latency
This panel shows store-gateway query requests from just the main query path (ie. excluding the ruler query path, if enabled). The data shown is as reported by queriers.
panels.title: Latency

panels.description:
### Per querier pod p99 latency
This panel shows store-gateway query requests from just the main query path (ie. excluding the ruler query path, if enabled). The data shown is as reported by queriers.
panels.title: Per querier pod p99 latency

rows.title: Store-gateway - query requests from this query path only

panels.description:
### Replicas
The maximum, and current number of querier replicas.
panels.title: Replicas

panels.description:
### Scaling metric (desired replicas)
This panel shows the result scaling metric exposed by KEDA divided by the target/threshold used.
It should represent the desired number of replicas, ignoring the min/max constraints which are applied later.

targets.expr:
sum by (scaler) (
  label_replace(
    keda_scaler_metrics_value{cluster=~"$cluster", exported_namespace=~"$namespace"},
    "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.*)"
  )
  /
  on(cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) group_left
  max by (cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) (
    label_replace(label_replace(
        kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?querier"},
        "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
    ), "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?(.*)")
  )
)

panels.title: Scaling metric (desired replicas)

panels.description:
### Autoscaler failures rate
The rate of failures in the KEDA custom metrics API server. Whenever an error occurs, the KEDA custom
metrics server is unable to query the scaling metric from Prometheus so the autoscaler wouldn't work properly.

targets.expr:
sum by(cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject, scaler) (
  label_replace(
    rate(keda_scaler_errors[$__rate_interval]),
    "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.+)"
  )
) +
on(cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject) group_left
  # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
  max by (cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject) (
    label_replace(
      label_replace(
          kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?querier"} * 0,
          "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?(.*)"
      ),
      "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
    )
  )

panels.title: Autoscaler failures rate

rows.title: Store-gateway  key-value store for store-gateways ring

targets.expr:
histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.50, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="index-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

panels.description:
### Hit ratio
Even if you do not set up memcached for the blocks index cache, you will still see data in this panel because the store-gateway by default has an
in-memory blocks index cache.
panels.title: Hit ratio

targets.expr:
histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="chunks-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.50, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="chunks-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="metadata-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.50, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((store-gateway.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="store-gateway",
  name="metadata-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.99, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((querier.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="querier",
  name="metadata-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

histogram_quantile(0.50, sum(rate(thanos_cache_operation_duration_seconds_bucket{
  cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((querier.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-read.*))",
  operation="getmulti",
  component="querier",
  name="metadata-cache"
}
[$__rate_interval])) by (le)) * 1e3

list.description: Choose between showing latencies based on low precision classic or high precision native histogram metrics.
list.label: Latency metrics
list.name: latency_metrics

panels.description:
### Reads from ingesters - RPS
Note: Even while operating in Remote ruler mode you will still see values for this panel.

This is because the metrics are inclusive of intermediate services and are showing the requests that ultimately reach the ingesters.

For a more detailed view of the read path when using remote ruler mode, see the Remote ruler reads dashboard.
panels.title: Reads from ingesters - RPS

rows.title: Ruler - key-value store for rulers ring

panels.title: Number of store-gateways hit per query
Refetches of missing blocks per query

panels.description:
### Consistency checks failed
Rate of queries that had to run with consistency checks and those checks failed. A failed consistency check means that some of at least one block which had to be queried wasn't present in any of the store-gateways.
panels.title: Consistency checks failed

list.description: Choose between showing latencies based on low precision classic or high precision native histogram metrics.
list.label: Latency metrics
list.name: latency_metrics

panels.content: This dashboard shows various metrics detailed by tenant (user) selected above.

panels.description:
### All series
Number of active, in-memory, and owned series per user, and active series matching custom trackers (in parenthesis).
Note that these counts include all series regardless of the type of data (counter, gauge, native histogram, etc.).
Note that active series matching custom trackers are included in the total active series count.
panels.title: All series

panels.description:
### In-memory series per ingester
Local tenant series limit and number of in-memory series per ingester.
Because series can be unevenly distributed across ingesters, ingesters may hit the local limit at different times.
Note that in-memory series may exceed the local limit if limiting based on owned series is enabled.
panels.title: In-memory series per ingester

panels.description:
### Owned series per ingester
Local tenant series limit and number of owned series per ingester.
Because series can be unevenly distributed across ingesters, ingesters may hit the local limit at different times.
Owned series are the subset of an ingester's in-memory series that currently map to it in the ring
panels.title: Owned series per ingester

panels.description:
### Series with exemplars
Number of series with exemplars currently in storage.
panels.title: Series with exemplars

panels.description:
### Oldest exemplar age
The age of the oldest exemplar stored in circular storage.
Useful to check for what time range the current exemplar buffer limit allows.
This usually means the max age for all exemplars for a typical setup.
This is not true though if one of the series timestamp is in future compared to rest series.
panels.title: Oldest exemplar age

panels.description:
### Native histogram series
Number of active native histogram series per user, and active native histogram series matching custom trackers (in parenthesis).
Note that active series matching custom trackers are included in the total active series count.
panels.title: Native histogram series

panels.description:
### Total number of buckets used by native histogram series
Total number of buckets in active native histogram series per user, and total active native histogram buckets matching custom trackers (in parenthesis).
panels.title: Total number of buckets used by native histogram series

panels.description:
### Distributor requests incoming rate
The rate of requests that have come in to the distributor, including rejected requests.
panels.title: Distributor requests incoming rate

panels.description:
### Distributor requests received (accepted) rate
The rate of received requests, excluding rejected requests.
panels.title: Distributor requests received (accepted) rate

panels.description:
### Newest seen sample age
The age of the newest received sample seen in the distributors.
panels.title: Newest seen sample age

panels.description:
### Distributor discarded requests rate
The rate of each request's discarding reason.
panels.title: Distributor discarded requests rate

panels.description:
### Distributor samples incoming rate
The rate of samples that have come in to the distributor, including rejected or deduped exemplars.
panels.title: Distributor samples incoming rate

panels.description:
### Distributor samples received (accepted) rate
The rate of received samples, excluding rejected and deduped samples.
panels.title: Distributor samples received (accepted) rate

panels.description:
### Distributor deduplicated/non-HA
The rate of deduplicated samples and the rate of received samples for a user that has HA tracking turned on, but the sample didn't contain both HA labels.
panels.title: Distributor deduplicated/non-HA

panels.description:
### Distributor and ingester discarded samples rate
The rate of each sample's discarding reason.
This doesn't account for the replication factor.
panels.title: Distributor and ingester discarded samples rate

panels.description:
### Out-of-order samples appended
The rate of OOO samples that have been appended.
This doesn't account for the replication factor.
panels.title: Out-of-order samples appended

panels.description:
### Distributor exemplars incoming rate
The rate of exemplars that have come in to the distributor, including rejected or deduped exemplars.
panels.title: Distributor exemplars incoming rate

panels.description:
### Distributor exemplars received (accepted) rate
The rate of received exemplars, excluding rejected and deduped exemplars.
This number can be sensibly lower than incoming rate because we dedupe the HA sent exemplars, and then reject based on time.
See discarded rate for reasons why exemplars are being discarded.
panels.title: Distributor exemplars received (accepted) rate

panels.description:
### Distributor discarded exemplars rate
The rate of each exmplars' discarding reason.
panels.title: Distributor discarded exemplars rate

panels.description:
### Ingester appended exemplars rate
Total number of exemplars appended in the ingesters.
This can be lower than ingested exemplars rate since TSDB does not append the same exemplar twice, and those can be frequent.
This doesn't account for the replication factor.
panels.title: Ingester appended exemplars rate

panels.description:
### Symbol table size for loaded blocks
Size of symbol table in memory for loaded blocks, averaged by ingester.
panels.title: Symbol table size for loaded blocks

panels.description:
### Space used by local blocks
The number of bytes that are currently used for local storage by all blocks.
panels.title: Space used by local blocks

panels.description:
### Number of groups
Total number of rule groups for a tenant.
panels.title: Number of groups

panels.description:
### Number of rules
Total number of rules for a tenant.
panels.title: Number of rules

targets.expr:
(
sum(rate(cortex_alertmanager_notifications_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((alertmanager|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))", user="$user"}[$__rate_interval]))
-
on() (sum(rate(cortex_alertmanager_notifications_failed_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((alertmanager|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))", user="$user"}[$__rate_interval])) or on () vector(0))
) > 0

(
sum(rate(cortex_alertmanager_notifications_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((alertmanager|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))", user="$user"}[$__rate_interval])) by(integration)
-
(sum(rate(cortex_alertmanager_notifications_failed_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((alertmanager|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))", user="$user"}[$__rate_interval])) by(integration) or
 (sum(rate(cortex_alertmanager_notifications_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((alertmanager|cortex|mimir|mimir-backend.*))", user="$user"}[$__rate_interval])) by(integration) * 0)
)) > 0

panels.description:
### Number of Queries Queued - query-scheduler

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Number of Queries Queued - query-scheduler

panels.description:
### Number of Queries Queued - ruler-query-scheduler

The query-scheduler is an optional service that moves the internal queue from the query-frontend into a separate component. If the query-scheduler is not deployed, these panels will show "No data."
panels.title: Number of Queries Queued - ruler-query-scheduler

panels.description:
### Estimated Compaction Jobs
Estimated number of compaction jobs for selected user, based on latest version of bucket index. When user sends data, ingesters upload new user blocks every 2 hours
(shortly after 01:00 UTC, 03:00 UTC, 05:00 UTC, etc.), and compactors should process all of the blocks within 2h interval.
If this graph regularly goes to zero (or close to zero) in 2 hour intervals, then compaction for this user works correctly.

Depending on the configuration, there are two types of jobs: `split` jobs and `merge` jobs. Split jobs will only show up when user is configured with positive number of `compactor_split_and_merge_shards`.
Values for split and merge jobs are stacked.
panels.title: Estimated Compaction Jobs

panels.description:
### Number of blocks
Number of blocks stored in long-term storage for this user.
panels.title: Blocks

panels.content: This dashboard shows the top tenants based on multiple selection criterias. Rows are collapsed by default to avoid querying all of them. Use the templating variable "limit" above to select the amount of users to be shown.

panels.title: Top $limit users by in-memory series (series created - series removed)
Top $limit users by in-memory series (series created - series removed) that grew the most between query range start and query range end
Top $limit users by received samples rate in last 5m

targets.expr:
sum by (user) (rate(cortex_distributor_received_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval]))
and
topk($limit,
  sum by (user) (rate(cortex_distributor_received_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval] @ end()))
  -
  sum by (user) (rate(cortex_distributor_received_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval] @ start()))
)

panels.title: Top $limit users by received samples rate that grew the most between query range start and query range end
Top $limit users by discarded samples rate in last 5m

targets.expr:
sum by (user) (rate(cortex_discarded_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((ingester.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*|distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval]))
and
topk($limit,
  sum by (user) (rate(cortex_discarded_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((ingester.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*|distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval] @ end()))
  -
  sum by (user) (rate(cortex_discarded_samples_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"($namespace)/((ingester.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*|distributor.*|cortex|mimir|mimir-write.*))"}[$__rate_interval] @ start()))
)

panels.title: Top $limit users by discarded samples rate that grew the most between query range start and query range end
Top $limit users by series with exemplars
Top $limit users by received exemplars rate in last 5m
Top $limit users by estimated compaction jobs from bucket-index

rows.title: By estimated compaction jobs from bucket-index

panels.content:
This dashboard shows various health metrics for the write path. It is broken into sections for each service on the write path, and organized by the order in which the write request flows.
Incoming metrics data travels from the gateway distributor ingester.
For each service, there are 3 panels showing (1) requests per second to that service, (2) average, median, and p99 latency of requests to that service, and (3) p99 latency of requests to each instance of that service.

It also includes metrics for the key-value (KV) stores used to manage the high-availability tracker and the ingesters.

panels.description:
### Exemplars / sec
The total number of received exemplars by the distributors, excluding rejected and deduped exemplars, but not necessarily ingested by the ingesters.
panels.title: Exemplars / sec

panels.description:
### In-memory series
The number of series not yet flushed to object storage that are held in ingester memory.
With classic storage we the sum of series from all ingesters is divided by the replication factor.
With ingest storage we take the maximum series of each ingest partition.
panels.title: In-memory series

panels.description:
### Exemplars in ingesters
Number of TSDB exemplars currently in ingesters' storage.
With classic storage we the sum of exemplars from all ingesters is divided by the replication factor.
With ingest storage we take the maximum exemplars of each ingest partition.
panels.title: Exemplars in ingesters

panels.description:
### Requests / sec
The rate of successful, failed and rejected requests to distributor.
Rejected requests are requests that distributor fails to handle because of distributor instance limits.
When distributor is configured to use "early" request rejection, then rejected requests are NOT included in other metrics.
When distributor is not configured to use "early" request rejection, then rejected requests are also counted as "errors".
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Requests / sec
The rate of successful, failed and rejected requests to ingester.
Rejected requests are requests that ingester fails to handle because of ingester instance limits (ingester-max-inflight-push-requests, ingester-max-inflight-push-requests-bytes, ingester-max-ingestion-rate).
When ingester is configured to use "early" request rejection, then rejected requests are NOT included in other metrics.
When ingester is not configured to use "early" request rejection, then rejected requests are also counted as "errors".
panels.title: Requests / sec

panels.description:
### Replicas
The minimum, maximum, and current number of distributor replicas.
panels.title: Replicas

panels.description:
### Scaling metric (CPU): Desired replicas
This panel shows the scaling metric exposed by KEDA divided by the target/threshold used.
It should represent the desired number of replicas, ignoring the min/max constraints applied later.

targets.expr:
sum by (scaler) (
  # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
  max by (cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric, scaler) (
    label_replace(
      keda_scaler_metrics_value{cluster=~"$cluster", exported_namespace=~"$namespace", scaler=~".*cpu.*"},
      "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.*)"
    )
  )
  /
  on(cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) group_left
    # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
    max by (cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) (
      label_replace(
        label_replace(
          kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?distributor"},
          "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
        ),
        "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?(.*)"
      )
    )
)

panels.title: Scaling metric (CPU): Desired replicas

panels.description:
### Scaling metric (memory): Desired replicas
This panel shows the scaling metric exposed by KEDA divided by the target/threshold used.
It should represent the desired number of replicas, ignoring the min/max constraints applied later.

targets.expr:
sum by (scaler) (
  # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
  max by (cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric, scaler) (
    label_replace(
      keda_scaler_metrics_value{cluster=~"$cluster", exported_namespace=~"$namespace", scaler=~".*memory.*"},
      "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.*)"
    )
  )
  /
  on(cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) group_left
    # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
    max by (cluster, namespace, scaledObject, metric) (
      label_replace(
        label_replace(
          kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?distributor"},
          "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
        ),
        "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?(.*)"
      )
    )
)

panels.title: Scaling metric (memory): Desired replicas

panels.description:
### Autoscaler failures rate
The rate of failures in the KEDA custom metrics API server. Whenever an error occurs, the KEDA custom
metrics server is unable to query the scaling metric from Prometheus so the autoscaler wouldn't work properly.

targets.expr:
sum by(cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject, scaler) (
  label_replace(
    rate(keda_scaler_errors[$__rate_interval]),
    "namespace", "$1", "exported_namespace", "(.+)"
  )
) +
on(cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject) group_left
  # Using `max by ()` so that series churn doesn't break the promQL join
  max by (cluster, namespace, metric, scaledObject) (
    label_replace(
      label_replace(
          kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_target_metric{cluster=~"$cluster", namespace=~"$namespace", horizontalpodautoscaler=~"keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?distributor"} * 0,
          "scaledObject", "$1", "horizontalpodautoscaler", "keda-hpa-(?:mimir-)?(.*)"
      ),
      "metric", "$1", "metric_name", "(.+)"
    )
  )

panels.title: Autoscaler failures rate

rows.title: Distributor - key-value store for high-availability (HA) deduplication
Distributor - key-value store for distributors ring
Ingester - key-value store for the ingesters ring

panels.description:
### Uploaded blocks / sec
The rate of blocks being uploaded from the ingesters
to object storage.
panels.title: Uploaded blocks / sec

panels.description:
### Upload latency
The average, median (50th percentile), and 99th percentile time
the ingesters take to upload blocks to object storage.
panels.title: Upload latency

panels.description:
### Compactions per second
Ingesters maintain a local TSDB per-tenant on disk. Each TSDB maintains a head block for each
active time series; these blocks get periodically compacted (by default, every 2h).
This panel shows the rate of compaction operations across all TSDBs on all ingesters.
panels.title: Compactions / sec

panels.description:
### Compaction latency
The average, median (50th percentile), and 99th percentile time ingesters take to compact TSDB head blocks
on the local filesystem.
panels.title: Compactions latency

panels.description:
### WAL truncations per second
The WAL is truncated each time a new TSDB block is written. This panel measures the rate of
truncations.
panels.title: WAL truncations / sec

panels.description:
### Checkpoints created per second
Checkpoints are created as part of the WAL truncation process.
This metric measures the rate of checkpoint creation.
panels.title: Checkpoints created / sec

panels.description:
### WAL truncations latency (including checkpointing)
Average time taken to perform a full WAL truncation,
including the time taken for the checkpointing to complete.
panels.title: WAL truncations latency (includes checkpointing)

panels.description:
### Distributor exemplars incoming rate
The rate of exemplars that have come in to the distributor, including rejected or deduped exemplars.
panels.title: Distributor exemplars incoming rate

panels.description:
### Distributor exemplars received rate
The rate of received exemplars, excluding rejected and deduped exemplars.
This number can be sensibly lower than incoming rate because we dedupe the HA sent exemplars, and then reject based on time, see `cortex_discarded_exemplars_total` for specific reasons rates.
panels.title: Distributor exemplars received rate

panels.description:
### Ingester ingested exemplars rate
The rate of exemplars ingested in the ingesters.
Every exemplar is replicated to a number of ingesters. With classic storage we the sum of rates from all ingesters is divided by the replication factor.
With ingest storage we take the maximum rate of each ingest partition.
This ingested exemplars rate should match the distributor's received exemplars rate.
panels.title: Ingester ingested exemplars rate

panels.description:
### Ingester appended exemplars rate
The rate of exemplars appended in the ingesters.
This can be lower than ingested exemplars rate since TSDB does not append the same exemplar twice, and those can be frequent.
panels.title: Ingester appended exemplars rate

list.description: Choose between showing latencies based on low precision classic or high precision native histogram metrics.
list.label: Latency metrics
list.name: latency_metrics
